text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Amsterdam options exchange manages to avoid gridlock. (p1)
- Port services company Hes Beheer expects to book record losses in first half due to a number of one-off charges. (p1)
- Estate agents see the rise of house prices in the Netherlands slowing as more new houses come on the market. (p4)
- Stockbrokers Amsterdam Options Traders AOT
doubles first half net to Dfl 20.9 million. (p9)
VOLKSKRANT
- Holland Media Group HMG's broadcasting company RTL 4 begins assault on public broadcasters and private channel SBS 6 with introduction of current affairs programme. (p1)
- Oil exploring company NAM accused of drilling for gas in the Wadden Sea. (p2)
- Thai police raid ABN Amro Hoare Govett office.
DE TELEGRAAF
- Mulder Boskoop will np;ot be an intermediary for its stakeholders' businesses. (p21)
- Accountancy Coopers & Lybrand involved in legal battle over Dfl 651 million claim. (p21)
- Demand for high quality office space grows sharply in the first half of 1997. (p23)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Offshore firm HeereMac accused of unfair competition in the U.S. (p11)
- Transhipment company ECT talks with unions about new social plan for staff of bankrupt Bell Line . (p11)
TROUW
- Some 235 jobs have to go in new restructuring round at shipbuilder Koninklijke Schelde. (p1)
